channel.title: strings on Shubham Chadokar
channel.description: Recent content in strings on Shubham Chadokar

item.title: Compare Strings in Golang
item.description: A string value is a sequence of bytes. Using the Comparison operators == equal != not equal < less <= less or equal > greater >= greater or equal To check if strings are equal or not, you can use == or !=. package main import ( "fmt" ) func main() { str1 := "golang" str2 := "gopher" fmt.Println(str1 == str2) fmt.Println(str1 != str2) } Output false true To check the Lexicographic Order of 2 strings, you can use <, <=, >, >=.

item.title: How to Join Strings in Golang?
item.description: There are multiple ways to join or concat strings in the golang. Let's start with the easy one. Using the + operator ðŸ”§ package main import ( "fmt" ) func main() { str1 := "Hello" // there is a space before World str2 := " World!" fmt.Println(str1 + str2) } Output Hello World! Using Sprint, Sprintf, Sprintln ðŸ› The fmt package has Sprint, Sprintf and Sprintln function which can format the strings using the default or custom formats.
